Quand les fièvres ou une longue et douloureuse maladie ont réduit le corps à un inquiétant état de faiblesse et d'amaigrissement, un reconstituant qui vous remettra promptement est nécessaire.

div.head: "EMPIRE DAY."
div.p: We are now within a short spell of an anniversary already endeared by moving and splendid memories to the British peoples throughout the world, and destined in the future, as we think, to be observed with universal consent as thefte-day of the Empi Upon May 24, 1819, "in a palace in a garden to recall the romantic phrase of her favor Minister, Queen Victoria was born under nobler horoscope than was in human insight to forecast. In personal excellence amd dign of character she was surpassed by none of 1 predecessors. The national age to which gave her name was one of the greatest in annals, and, in some respects, the most for nate in the history of any people. Her subject regarded her as time passed on with an exampled affection, of which the recollect lingers still like the afterglow of some sunset The influence of that sentiment all her peoples as one household The British Empire came to the consciousness of its before the close of that memorable reign, a if its political union should he cemented on the sceptre of his present Majesty the work federation will rise upon the foundations during the lifetime of our late Sovereign these reasons "Empire Day" throughout Colonies and in India is synonymous with Victoria Day. At home the efforts of L. Meath and his friends to secure the observation of May 24th as a national holiday are meet year by year with increasing success. Educational authorities in a number of districts agreed that an hour or two shall be devoted teaching British children, the citizens of. future, the nature of the "unequalled inheritance" of which it is one of our first duties make them the worthy heirs Here, at least an example which ought to be followed every school throughout the length breadth of the Empire, and let us hope the time will come when the definite teach of patriotism and the intelligent cultivation the sense of Imperial responsibility will promoted by the express direction of the State. No adequate steps are taken at home to the children of the people in the concept: of historic honor, national strength, Impeduty. Then we not infrequently complain t when these hoys and girls become men and women they do not show a sufficiently vigorous growth of the spirit which we have d nothing to implant in them. "Empire Day may in this respect become the means correcting one of the conspicuous defeat our character as an Imperial people, co-trust with the Colonies of an unparalleled dominate which it remains for us now to keep or give up."Nothing is more certain than that Mother Country and the Colonies can maintain their common interests against increasing pressure of a changing world thorough application of mind to the task. need a festival like "Empire Day" to help this purpose throughout the King's domination by making the British peoples one in imperialism thought and sentiment upon at least one of the year. Englishmen have held their fortune upon such easy terms since Wate that they had almost ceased to remember recently that "past politics" were the hasi 'present history." We have been content remain without anything in the nature of Imperial fete-day. The Primrose League new example by securing the permanent observance of the anniversary of a states who had identified himself closely in national imagination with the idea of Empire Trafalgar Day, in its turn, was regarded sour disfavor by the Radical reaction as other fantastic innovation repugnant to fine old crusted habits of political thou upon which the Liberal party still re Since then the celebration of the memory of Nelson and of the greatest sea victory ever won has become with general acceptance a regular national event. But even Trafa Day does not adequately fill the irregular in the patriotic calendar. Almost every of modern people keeps the anniversary o delivrance from tyranny or of the achievement of its national union. We have nothing corresponds to the American Fourth of J and every citizen of the Republic will as us that the loss is ours, and that we miss opportunity of stirring the imagination of masses in devotion to the flag France her nationial fete upon July 14th, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille since 1789 the Monarchists across the have had no festival which could compe inspiring associations with the birthday Revolution. Reunited Italy celebrates "Venti Settembre" when the Sardinian breached the walls of Rome. The Ge Empire in the same way commemorates i birth upon the anniversaries of the making battles of 1870. Let it be our hop will that "Empire Day'' shall become i turn, sooner or later, the festival of the; ation between the Mother Country ar Colonies, involving common measures fo perial development, as well as common sures for Imperial defence, that shall coping-stone upon the solid structure of political union At present the day is kept public holiday in Canada, South Africa, ] and New Zealand, and in Australia it is ally, though not legally, recognised.Without the definite co operation of a parts of the Empire, represented, as we by the Imperial Council of the future, be impossible for Great Britain to maintain commercial and naval supremacy sir gleha or to extend to the Colonies and Indian impregnable protection that we give them Unionists who disagree with Mr. Chamb' may refuse to think more Imperially that did before the historic Birmingham let them at least beware that they do not into the habit of thinking less Imperially before. There is some need for this was. We may disagree about the remedies applied. Thoughtful Englishmen cannot about the nature and the gravity problem to he approached, and, remember that sentiment is no substitute for construct policy, those who reject the fiscal so must propose, if they can, another meant making Empire Day the federal festival achieved Imperial union.

div.head: Alexandria and Cairo Bourses.
div.p: The Finance Ministry has granted the sum of £7,000 for the installation of a telephone line between the Alexandria and Cairo Bourses.

div.head: The Eldorado Theatre.
div.p: Four debuts are billed at the Eldorado theatre for this evening, namely Les de Bernys, duettists, the Sisters Dantes, Rosina de Franchi, and Lina Claris and Italia de Franchi.

div.head: The Census.
div.p: The criticisms as to the results of the taking of the census in Alexandria and Cairo are to the effect that there has been a most manifest lack of organisation as the increases of popula-tion in both cities are obviously far below, the actual figures.

div.head: Drowning Fatality at Boulao.
div.p: A native workman, engaged on board one of Cook's boats at their Boulac works, fell overboard yesterday in an effort to save a plate which had slipped over the side. The man was drowned and his body was not

div.head: Pearl Pin Found.
div.p: We are requested by the secretary of the Alexandria Sporting Club to give notice that after the races held on Saturday afternoon a gold pin with a large "pearl drop" head was found. The same can *be obtained by the owner on application at the office of the "Egyptian Gazette," Alexandria.

div.head: Plague Bulletin.
div.p: Sixteen fresh cases of plague have been announced during the last 24 hours of which eight cases have resulted fatally and two have been cured: the remainder are under treatment. The total number of cases this year is 639, of which 483 ended fatally, 95 recovered and 67 cases are still under treatment.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: The opening ball of the San Stefano Casino, for subscribers only, will take place next Saturday evening, and on Sunday the afternoon orchestral concerts also will commence, concerts also being given on Sunday mornings. The subscription for one person for the season is P.T. 200, and for a family P.T. 350.

div.head: Double Execution
div.p: Ismail Said Ahmed, 40 years of age, and Mohamed Ahmed, 28 years of age, convicted, of having murdered Ibrahim Khalaf at Kafr el Dawar on January 18, were hung at Hadra prison this morning in the presence of Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Kaimakam Cobbe Bey, Hashem Bey, and a few Press representatives. Both men on the scaffold exclaimed "Ana Mazloum," which may be freely interpreted as "I am wrongly condemned."

div.head: Raid on Tramps.
div.p: We must congratulate the Greek Consulate in Cairo in having taken an excellent initiative by arresting 39 Greeks without employment. This might, with the best results, be followed by other Consulates. To the observer there are a sufficient number of ne'er-do-wells loafing round both Alexandria and Cairo, and, as has been seen by recent communications to the Press, some of these gentry are sufficiently undesirable.

div.head: Alexandria Archaeological Society.
div.p: The Society in accordance with an agreement made with the Administrator of the • Alexandria Municipality will shortly present its members with the new guide to the city and museum, which Professor Breccia has prepared on behalf of the Municipality. The members of the committee of the society elected for the year 1907-1908, are as follows: Mr. Amb. A. Ralli, Rear Admiral Blomfield, Dr. Schiess Pasha, Lady Blomfield, Mr. P. Chata-way. G. Norsa Bey, Mr. E. B. Gould, Dr. Osborne, Hamdoullah Emine Pasha, Poilay Bey, Simond Bey, and M. Malaval.

div.head: Union Artistique Francaise.
div.p: On Saturday, the above association gave a social evening party and concert, which was attended by a large number of members and guests. The programme was made up of vocal and instrumental items relieved here and there by domic recitations. Mr. Gateau, was not very happy in the choice of his monologues: he forgot he was not at a smoking concert, and the presence of a great many ladies in the audience should have made him more careful in the selection of his pieces. The various perfumers did their very best to entertain the friends who came to hear them, more especially Mr. Sikich, tenor, who although quite an amateur still untrained, sang with feeling and great earnestness. Mr. P. Levy is certainly endowed with humourous powers, which he used very successfully in bringing the concert to a close and filling the air with merriment The room was then cleared and a "sauterie" agreeably ended this friendly meeting. On the whole the organisers and members of the committee must have felt satisfied with the result of their efforts, and the association deserves credit for trying its best to please every one and gradually realize its purpose.

div.head: THE ABOUKIR COMPANY.
div.p: The accounts of the Aboukir Company for the year 1906 show a credit balance of £99,437, which, added to £33,468 brought forward, makes £132,906 : deducting the dividends of 7 per cent, which have been paid during the year on the old ordinary and deferred shares, and the bonus of £5 per share on the old ordinary £5 shares, there remains a balance to carry forward of £26,236.

The committee of the London Stock Exchange has ordered the following security to be quoted in the Official List : — Further issue of £20,500 five per cent, first debentures of £100 each, Nos. 936 to 1,140.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH.HOME PRESS OPINION.
div.p: Lord Cromer's farewell speech has made a profound impression upon the native population of Cairo. "For the first time," says the "Timed," " he Egyptian people have heard, from Lord Cromer's own lips, an account and a defence, of Lord Cromer's policy. He has told them that be entered upon has task with two objects in view—the restoration of a good understanding with France and the introduction of a libera! spirit into a system of government 'which, of necessity, is bureaucratic.' He has witnessed the fulfilment of the first and he willingly leaves others to judge how far he has accomplished the second. He speaks with the scorn winch it merits of the allegation that, while the material prosperity of Egypt has been developed, her moral and* intellectual advance-ment has been neglected. He points to what has been achieved in the field of education, and he welcomes the 'very competent and ex-has been achieved and he welcomes cellent ally'who has recently appeared in it." MORNING TOST." Lord Cromer's speech will long be remembered as one of those felicitous utterances which throw lighten the, secrets of statesmanship, while it does down the two the guiding mothonour to the man . He laid principal ends which have been motives of his policy, as the res-toration of a good understanding with France, and the moral and intellectual advancement of the Egyptian people. Both have been achieved The future is equally assured if the warning of the statesman who is now leaving Egypt, but whose voice in England cannot be lightly disregarded, is laid to heart by those who on a superficial acquaintance with the country would echange the 'steady jog-trot' of the experienced administrator for a reckless gallop."

div.head: "STANDARD."
div.p: "From first to last, the great Egyptian Consul has dealt faithfully, with the ' trust committed to his charge ; in his own phrase, his policy has been simply 'to tell the truth' ; and his valedictory speech, charged though it is with warning, ends appropriately with a word of honest confidence and encouragement. Lord Cromer begs his successor to "Be of good cheer" ; and so he passes, full of honor and followed by the gratitude of two nations, to his late and hard-earned leisure."

div.head: "DAILY TELEGRAPH."
div.p: "The three hundred British troops that thronged the gallery represent the backbone of that steady, resolute, and fearless policy by which Lord Cromer extricated Egypt from bankruptcy and anarchy to a position which may well be envied by most of the great Powers. The presence and applause of the diplomatic representatives must have recalled to Cromer the innumerable single-handed fights he had successfully engaged in, when political intrigue arid financial jealousies were employed to defeat his single-minded purpose of putting Egypt on asound political and economic basis."

div.head: RADICAL VIEWS.
div.p: in his farewell speech at Cairo, justified a personal career which marked by the exercise of something

"Lord Cromer, abundantly justified has been marked approaching autocratic. power, and he right fully claims the gratitude of the Egyptian people for a splendid record of reforms accomplished in a land that was as corrupt as it was impoverished "

div.head: "CHRONICLE."
div.p: "If Lord Cromer had really been a king, say in the England (if 700 years ago, we may imagine how loudly history Would praise him. He would stand side by side with kings like Henry
IL or Edward must judge him. certainly
I, and it is as such that we Compared to his task, theirs not more arduous, and his
achievement has been at least as high. Like theirs, his qualities have been peculiarly English, but (if the best kind—integrity, patience, and reticence."

div.head: "DAILY NEWS."
div.p: "Lord Cromer's farewell to the country he has governed with such success and distinction was necessarily moving and touching occasion. In his retrospect of his long career he was able to point to triumphs of statesmanship and administrations of which nobody could have dreamt twenty years ago. . . . . .

But there remains one side of England's work still unaccomplished, and Lord Cromer's successor has to find the means of satisfying native ambitions that are not only honourable in themselves, but symptoms of the success we have gained "

div.head: LAND AND MORTGAGE COMPANY OF EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. R. A. Huri has joined the board of the Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt in the place of Viscount Hampden, deceased.

It is announced that debenture interest coupons due on the 15th inst. of the Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt, and also the Debenture Bonds(drawn for redemption), will be paid on and after that date by Messrs. Barclay and Go.

div.head: SOCIETE COMMERCIALE D'EGYPTE.
div.p: Mr. Michel Sinadino, one of the founders of the Societe Commerciale d'Egypte and chairman of the Board of Directors of that Company, is retiring from active participation in the management of the Company after a connection of twenty two years

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RECEPTION. GREAT BRITAIN'S CONFIDENCE.
div.p: The great honours with which Lord Cromer's arrival in London is to be marked have already been announced in our telegrams. The "Spectator" remarks."

Owing to the unfortunate event of Lord Cromer's health breaking down at a period of fierce agitation, they (the Egyptian people) are inclined to believe that Lord Cromer fell owing to want of support in England, and to believe also that the same fate awaits his successor. That being so, it is most important that not only the Government, but the whole of the British nation, should through some visible and public act show their continued confidence in Lord Cromer, and therefore in the policy which his successor is authorised by the British Government to maintain. It is not for us to suggest the method by which this most important fact should be emphasised, but we have little doubt that when the proper moment comes the King, acting, as he so often has acted before, as the representative of national feeling in its widest sense, will find the proper method of showing Egypt and the world how utterly ridiculous is the notion that Lord Cromer had lost the confidence of his Sovereign, of the Government, or of the British people. No doubt a vote of public money to Lord Cromer would have excellent result in this direction, but we venture to think that in addition to this some action of what we might call a more dramatic or spectacular kind, such as a public demonstration of welcome to Lord Cromer on his return home, is required.

div.head: KAMEL'S "RECKLESS POLICY."
div.p: In a letter to the "Times" on the Egyptian Nationalist movement, Mr. H. R. Fox Bourne, secretary of the Aborigines Protection Society, says :—

Allow me to point out to your readers that the main body of Egyptian reformers, w hose principal organs are "El Moayad" and "El Minbar", are not in harmony with the reckless policy of Mustapha Kamel Pasha and his followers, whose organs are "El Lewa" and its English and French reproductions, the "Egyptian Standard" and the "Etendard Egyptien." They aim, not at an overthrow of British control over Egypt, but at a gradual and statesmanlike development of internal self-government on the equitable lines started by Lord Dufferin and by the Organic Law of 1883, and repeatedly recommended and supported both by Mr. Gladstone's and Lord Salisbury's Governments. They recognize the splendid services rendered by Lord Cromer in promoting the material resources of Egypt, and the consequent improvement in many directions of the social condition of the people ; but they claim that the time has arrived for serious effort to be made towards solving what Sir Eldon Gorst, Lord Cromer's successor, admits in his supplementary chapter to Lord Milner's "England in Egypt," to be "a problem of much greater complexity" ; and of which Sir Eldon says "The solution will be found rather in the development of the instincts of the people in the direction of local self-government than in the introduction of European institutions unsuited to the genius of the Oriental character."

div.head:
THE KHARGA OASIS
AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS
div.p: The following information is taken from the weekly reports Agricultural operations in the Oasis of Kharga are proceeding satisfactorily. Wheat and barley crops are now all reaped. The general average of the crops being satisfactory especially considering that most are on second year lands. The yield from one plot of 5 feddans of first cultivation was 40 ardebs or 8 ardebs to the feddan. The cotton crop is looking well, and the plants have had a first thinning.

The flow of the wells has increased since December last by an average of about 20 gallons per well per minute for the larger number of wells bored, all running simultaneously. This increase is probably due to greater economy in shutting down wells when not actually required for irrigation. The areas for rice and melon cultivation during the summer are now ready, and sowing is in progress. Some plots of melons well up.

Arrangements are in progress for the transport and sale of the coming date crop Remunerative contracts for the supply of stone in the Farshut district have been secured. These will materially diminish the cost of such cutting as has been necessary on the plateau.

div.head: YEMEN PEACE COMMISSION.
div.p: The Yemen Peace Commission has arrived at Hodeida by special steamer and has left Sana.
Since I wrote you last the Turkish time Rediffs, who were* giving trouble to the people of Hodeida, have left.

div.p: River Transport of Goods between Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB-
div.p: Although the attendance was not so large as that of Monday, the second day's racing of the Second Summer Meeting attracted a fair number on Saturday afternoon. Excellent weather prevailed and this combined with the fashionable gathering and interesting sport made one of the most enjoyable afternoons we have spent at the Sporting Club. In some measure this may be due to the exceptionally exciting result of the last race, but it is not usual to take the last first, and other races being worthy of mention we will take them in the order of running.

The May Selling Race brought out five runners, Sadik being favorite, and the judgment was not misplaced as it easily disposed of Moofid and Mizzaud. Only four horses went to the post for the Lord of Rosna Handicap amongst them the consistent and victorious Carlton. His top weight of 10 stone 7 did not stop him, and

his fourth consecutive race on this course this season. Digby tried hard with Aurelius but the effort was useless and could only finish a good second. Carlton we understand is being sent to England shortly. Stillwell shone in the next three races and performed the "hat trick" by winning each, his mounts being Ragueh, Fadaan, and El Tahawi. As we have already mentioned the surprise of the day was the May Handicap for which a field of nine runners turned out. Nadim was fancied and made favorite. All got away well and the excitement did not commence until entering the straight when Dounghan and Ghazi separating themselves from the rest, with Nadim joining them, made a neck and neck race. Shouts went up for Nadim, and Stillwell tried hard to add his fourth victory, but Jenkins was not to be beaten, just getting Doughan home by a very narrow margin. Even then so close was the result that until the numbers went up it was generally accepted that Nadim bad won.
To add to the surprise of the win the pari mutuel paid out what we believe to be the record price of P.T. 1416 or over L.E. 14 to the dollar.

Referring to the Pari Mutuel reminds ns of what seems to be a matter of general complaint viz :—the difficulty in the first place of being attended to in the scramble to make a bet, and secondly the extraordinary length of time it is necessary to wait before winnings can be drawn after a race, in some instances not until the next race is being or has been run. We realise the task of making the necessary check and calculations must be a huge one but surely the delay is detrimental to their own interests as one cannot be waiting at the windows, and betting on the next race at the same time, to say nothing of the inconvenience in perhaps having to miss the following race, and we think some method of improvement could be made in this direction, even in increasing their staff.

div.head: MAKING THE SUEZ CANAL FREE.
div.p: Speaking at the Conference of Colonial Premiers and Ministers at the Colonial Office, Sir Joseph Ward, Premier of New Zealand, said that we ought to take a leaf out of the book of some of our rivals and assist shipping communications by subsidies. He would also, if he could, make the Suez Canal free, so as to prevent all obstacles to development. New Zealand would be prepared to take its part in providing the sum required. What he suggested might not be immediately feasible, but deserved consideration.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The exequatur, giving official recognition to Sir Eldon Gorst as H. B. M'.s Consul-General in Egypt, having arrived from Constantinople, Sir Eldon Gorst will be officially received by the Khedive at Ras el Tin Palace on Thursday.

Saba Pasha will retire from active work as Postmaster General on the 1st. proxo. His Excellency, however, will not definitely leave the service of the Egyptian Government until the 15th September as he has leave up to that time.

A Cairo newspaper declares that Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, President of the Council of Minister, will shortly retire and will be replaced by Saad Pasha Zaghloul, the Minister of Education. This rumour is officially stated to be baseless.
M. G. Vasquez y Lopez-Amor, Spanish Consul at Port Said, has been transferred in the same capacity to Alexandria vice M. Spagnolo, deceased.
Mr. Edgers, chief inspector of Museums, has been granted three months' leave to date from 4th June and Mr. Walsh, Sudan Irrigation Department, has been accorded three months' leave.
Mr. Percy Le Breton, the well-known barrister and son of Major Le Breton, leaves for Europe to-morrow on a well earned holiday.
Mr. H. Hesketh Bell, C.M G., K.M., commissioner for Uganda, is staying for a few days at Shepheard's Hotel on his way to England.
M. Laloe, the recently appointed judge to the Cairo Mixed Tribunal, arrived in Cairo yesterday morning and took charge of his post '
Mohamed Aly Scharara Bey, moudi of Keneh, and Moheb Pasha, Governor of the Suez Canal, have each obtained three months' leave.
Messrs. George Le wis and J. B. Manson have been appointed temporary correspondents of the "Egyptian Gazette" at Cairo.

To adopt an agreement for the purchase of the Zogheb properties in Cairo, Place de l'Opera, and Rues El-Manakh, Kasr-el-Nil and Zogheb, on the terms set out in a contract between Messrs. Alexandre, Michel and Charles de Zogheb, and Madame Isabelle Michalla Pacha, of the one part, and Mesars. Clement Suares, Fils and Co., Count Fran-cesco Salimei, and Pietro Tonti, of the other part, to acquire, hold, develop, sell, let, or otherwise deal with land or other immovable property in Egypt, the Sudan, or elsewheie ; to lay out building sites; to erect, alter, demolish, decorate, fit, improve, and maintain buildings and conveniences; to cultivate, plant, pave, drain, or let on building lease or agree-ment any of the company's land ; to advance money to and enter into contracts of any kind with builders, tenants, and others, and to carry on an investment, financial, and agency business. The signatories are :—A.Tilche, Alexandria, 250 ; J.E. de Menasce, Alexadria, 25) ; Pp. Salimei Francesco, Rome, proprietaire L. Adacher, 250; Ed Sasson, Alexandria, 250 ; F. Suares, Alexandria, 250; J. de Botton, Alexandria, five; V. Teissere, Alexandria, chief accountant de la Maison E. J. L. de Menasce, five. Minimum cash subscription, 0 per cent. of any shares offered to public. First directors (not less than three nor more than nine) : Baron Jacques E. de Menasce, Cav. Uff. A. Tilche, Count Francesco Salimei, and Edward Sasson. The first directors my appoint Count Michel de Zogheb as a director before the ordinary general meeting in 1908. They may also at any time appoint any other qualified person, subject to numerical limit, such director to hold office till the next ordinary general meeting and to be eligible for re-election. Qualification, 250 ordinary shares. Remuneration, 5 per cent, of the surplus profits after providing for special reserve fund and for the preferential dividend of 5 per cent. on the ordinary shares, divisible.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS LIMITED.
INTERESTING DETAILS OF THE BUSINESS.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the Egyptian Markets, Ltd., was hold on the 29th ulto at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, E.C., Mr. F. E. Robertson, C.I.E. (the Chairman of the company), presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. F. J. Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting and the auditors' report,

The Chairman said: Gentlemen,—As you have all had the report in your hands, I pre sume you will, as usual, take it as read ; and therefore, before moving that it be adopted, I will touch upon such points as will bear greater elaboration than is convenient in a formal re-port. First I will refer to the cattle plague. Last year, you may remember, I had to relate a sail disappointment ; the markets had all been opened, but on account of sporadic outbreaks of plague over 90 had again to be closed. Unfortunately, we are not yet absolutely free from interruption, but as each outbreak is shorter and more localised, thanks to the energetic measures taken by the Sanitary Department, wo have good grounds for hoping that before long wo shall bo entirely free from plague. At present 108 markets are open and 12 are closed. I am glad to tell you that Government are considering favourably a proposal for an increase in the number of our markets. Last year I also told you that we hoped to increase our revenue by selling in our markets artificial manures. The distribution of such fertilisers in Egypt has developed beyond expectation, and the result of the use of these manures for cereal crops has been highly satisfactory to that cultivation. The Khedivial Agricultural Society, which undertook the purchase and distribution tentatively, has now decided to relinquish the business as being outside its proper sphere of operations; and whereas we had only thought of acting as agents to the society for the sale, we now are in a position to undertake the provision and sale on our own account. It was a matter for consideration whether this could best be done by a subsidiary company, or whether the Markets should issue the 50,000 shares in hand, anil trade themselves Personally, I was rather in favour of the for-mer course, on accent of two disabilities under which our trading lies firstly, the sharing of profits with Government ; and secondly, having to pay a sinking found on the capital which earns the prefits. The Government having consented to forego their share of any profits of the nitrate business, and the sentiment of the shareholders in Egypt, who probably form a majority and should be in the best position to form an opinion, being very st rongly in favour of the Markets doing the business, it was finally decided to issue the 50,000 shares author ised but unissued, which was done at a premium of 7s Cd, a result on which I think wo may congratulate ourselves considering the very crippled state of our principal source of income, on account of the closing of our markets on account of cattle plague, during the past the three years. As to the sinking fund, it will have this pleasing result, that at the ex piration of our concession, the shareholders will not only get the £50,000 which it produces, but will remain in possession of any then existing stock of nitrates, which will' not be a wasting property like the capital sunk in land and buildings which revert to Government. We successfully placed the £15,000 debentures of which I spoke last year, and the proceeds are being spent in the erection of slaughterhouses, which we hope will not only yield us a good return, but indirectly strengthen our position by making the markets a more necessary resort.

The sale of salt in our markets as agents for the Port Said Salt Company, to which I referred when I last addressed you, has been carried on during part of the year, but the profits have not been as much as we had hoped on account of severe competition between that company and the Salt and Soda Company There is every prospect now of an agreement between the two companies which will be advantageous to us and put the sale of salt on a more businesslike footing. To further the interest in the markets, if not the direct profits, we have been considering the opening of agencies for the sale of coal and timber. For the first time we have obtained a small sum for the right of advertising in the markets. Among other projects I should mention one which we are now investigating—namely, the establishment of a general market at Port Said. The situation of that town is somewhat peculiar; it has, as you all know, the sea on one side, but perhaps you do not realise that on the other there is nothing but desert and swamps right up to Ismailia, half-way to Suez, so that there are no villagers to come into the market as a centre for business. Still, the town is a growing one. Docks and coaling stations are being constructed, and on general grounds the matter is worth investigation Having found that the market site at Benha-had, by reason of a remodelling of the rail way station, become exceedingly valuable, we acquired a new and much cheaper site, and hope to sell the old one at a profit quite worth taking, even though we have to share it with Government. I am glad to say that since the new market opened wo have had a record attendance showing that the change of site has not diminished our business. In consequence of all the miscellaneous business which we are undertaking it has been necessary to retransfer the accounts to Egypt and will be so to arrange for a local audit, subordinate' to that of your own auditors. The accounts were transferred to London on the ground of economy and all vouchers were sent over here and the accounts

kept here. That was possible and even convenient so long as we had nothing but weekly receipts and wages . to record, but with tho amplification of our business, the accounts must obviously be kept in full on the spot, where, indeed, some of them have to bo open to inspection and settled. As regards the accounts which are before you, they are quite simple and, I think, satisfactory, considering the hard measures dealt to us by cattle plague, anti I therefore do not propose to comment upon them.

div.head: DIRECTORS VISIT TO EGYPT.
div.p: Before I sit down I may toll you that I paid a short visit to Egypt in January to settle about taking up the nitrate business and Major Le Breton was there on other business from November to March, but gave much time to the details of the markets' business. To conclude, I think I can safely say that even should there still be sporadic cases of cattle plague we have turned the corner and, after all our anxieties, may look forward to yearly increasing prosperity. If there is any further information I can give I shall be happy to do so or to hear any remarks any shareholder may wish to make before I move the adoption of the report and accounts. (Applause.)

* No questions being asked, the Chairman moved the following resolution :—"That the report of the directors, dated 9th April, 1907, together with the audited statement of accounts and balance-sheet for the year ended 31st December, 1906, bo and they are hereby received, approved and adopted."
The motion was seconded by Sir Gerald Fitz-Gerald, and carried unanimously.

The Chairman : I now have to move : "That the interim dividend of 3 per cent, (subject to income-tax) declared on the ordinary share capital of the company and paid on 16th October, 1906, be and it is hereby confirmed, and that a further dividend of 4 per cent. (subject to income-tax), on the ordinary share capital of the company, making 7 per cent. for the year, be and it is hereby declared to be paid to the holders of ordinary shares recorded on the registers, of the company on 24th April, 1907, and to holders of ordinary share warrants to bearer."
This was seconded by Major W. I. Le Breton and adopted.
The Chairman : I now have the pleasure to move the re-election of Major W. I. Lo Breton, who is retiring in order of rotation.
Sir Gerald FitzGerald seconded this resolution, which was agreed to, and Major Lo Breton thanked the shareholders for his re-election.
The Chairman : I now have the pleasure in moving the re-election of Mr. G. B. Kerr, who also retires in order of rotation. He, you may know, is a member of the local Board, resident in Egypt.
The motion was seconded by Major W. I Le Breton and carried.

The Chairman : On Mr. Kerr's behalf I thank you, gentlemen. We now hare to consider the question of the audit of the com pany's, accounts and the election of auditors, to both of which subjects I have previously referred. For the London Work Messrs. Price Waterhouse and Company offer themselves for're-election at a fee of twenty-five guineas, but so far as the local Egyptian audit is concerned, we have not yet been able to arrange, and must ask you to leave the selection of competent auditors and their remuneration—for this year only that will be, of course —in the hands of the directors. Subject to your approval, I will now ask a shareholder to propose a resolution to that effect, and a second shareholder to second that resolution.

Mr. T. P. Singer : I beg to move : "That Messrs. Price Waterhouse and Company be elected auditors of the London accounts of this company for the ensuing year, at a remuneration of twenty five guineas, and that the selec-tion of auditors for the necessary audit in Egypt, and their remuneration for the ensuing year, be left to the discretion of the directors."
Mr. M. G. Bauer seconded the resolution, and it was carried.

The Chairman : Gentlemen, I now have to propose a resolution modifying the articles of association. In, this connection I should like to explain that in some manner or other, in the original drafting of the articles of associa tion an inconsistency crept in whereby article 85, which deals with the voting powers of holders of share warrants to bearer, is practically annulled by article 41. This inconsistency will be rectified by the passing of the resolution which I will now put to the meeting, and which as it involves an alteration of the articles of associations, will necessitate the convening of a subsequent confirmatory general meeting of the shareholders I will now move ; " That the articles of association be varied as follows, namely, by striking out from article 41 the words 'Except that ho shall not be entitled to vote by proxy at a general meeting,' occurring in lines 10 and 11 thereof. '' .
Sir Gerald Fitz Gerald seconded the resolu-tion, which was adopted unanimously.
A vote of thanks was passed to the Chairman, on the motion of Mr. Singer, seconded by Mr. Bauer, and the proceedings terminated.
( From Opr Own Correspondent. ) London,' May 2nd.
Lieutenant Beauchamp Seymour, King's Royal Rifle Corps, and Captain Williams, Army Veterinary Corps, have been seconded for service with the Khedive's army.

Colonel F.W.N.M'Cracken, D. S. ()., 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, who commanded that smart battalion during its recent stay in Egypt and the Sudan, has vacated the command, and has been succeeded by Major R.N. Gamble, D S.O , second in com-mand. The Berks are at Subathu, in the Punjab.
Second Lieutenant J F R. Hope. King's Royal Rifle Corps, in Egypt, has just been promoted lieutenant, after four and half years service in the "Green-jackets."

The close of the year will see the huge majority of the "short service" soldiers transferred from their regiments to the Reserve, and the army will know them no more. The three years' men were designed to more rapidly fill up the Reserve which had been depleted by the Boer War, and to a certain extent they answered very well, but as regimental soldiers they can scarcely be said to have proved a success. With only a very short period of soldiering to look forward, and a lengthened service in the Reserve, they had no inducement offered to them to learn, or rise in their profession, save when they extended their service. Even in this, they did not come up to anticipation, as the costly bounties paid to old soldiers in India and elswhere can vouch for. If commanding officers and non-commissioned officers had anything to say in the matter, there would be no more "short service men" in the army.

The War Office has just been "rubbing it in" —to use a vulgar, though expressive, phrase— in connection with officers who have been noted for employment in the King's African Rifles, West African Frontier Force, and other Colonial employment subsequently refusing their appointments. This it is pointed out, ha-enused much unnecessary inconvenience, and that when officers are no longer desirous of such appointments they should submit an application to that effect in order to have their names removed from the list. Recently, several officers declined the appointments hence the War Office's indignation. The lists for employment with both forces, and other Colonial employment, are still full up.

It is painfully evident that even the optimistic Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has no great faith in the Hague Conference—who has ?—and it is equally evident that the much longed for "Millennium" is yet in the very far off future, judging by the orders for ordanance laid with Armstrong, Whitworth & Co.,. Vickers, Sons, and Maxim, and the Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, by our own Admiralty and those of other nations for the 12 inch guns with which the new "Dreadnoughts" are to he armed. These 12 inch weapons are very costly, and their elaborate mountings and sighting apparatus are more costly still. The innovation of the Dreadnought types of battleship— each of which mounts a dozen of these huge guns—has given a boom to Woolwich, Sheffield, Barrow, and Elswick, and it is safe to say that the private firms will be kept continuously nt work in constructing the big guns for the foreign Dreadnoughts, the superiority of British built guns over those of other countries being undeniable. It was his British built guns and the superb men behind them which gave Togo his memorable victory over Rojestvensky in the Sea of Japan. One effect of the Dreadnoughts will be to hasten the obsoleteness of many of the older types of battleships, which up to recently were a not-to-be-despised factor in our own, and to a greater extent in other navies.

div.head: CRICKET.
RAILWAY v. STAFF DEPTS.
div.p: The Staff and Departments brought down a strong side to the Institute on Friday last. The home captain winning the toss took first knock. Revd. Burns and Windsor opened the innings and a splendid stand ensued between the two. When 6, Windsor was rather badly missed behind the wicket. Runs came very fait and it was not till Captain Young took up the ball that the partnership was broken Windsor then being bowled, the score having reached 85. A perfect rot then set in, the eighth wicket falling with the total at 115 Revd. Burns was then leg before with his score at 57. It was a splendid innings and the third time in succession that he has passed 50. The innings closed for 130. Capt. Young and Mr. B. Jordan both bowled splendidly especially the latter who accounted for seven of the home batsmen. The visitors did not do early so well as was expected. Three wicket fell for only 15. Young and Jordan then mule a hit of a stand but after the former had left the side went to pieces, the tenth wicket falling with only 70 on the board. Jordan was top scorer for the staff with a carefully compiled 22. The Railway men won by CO runs. Appended are the details of scores :—
Rev. J. T. Burns, l.b.w.b. Jordan 57
L. H. Lion, c. and b. Jordan 9
Lieut. Thomson, c. Wheal, b. Wilson ... 0
Capt. Young, c. and b. Burns 17 '
Sgt. Hendry, c. Burns, b. Wilson 4.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: La taux d'escompte libre eut remonté à Londres à 3 1/8. Ici la lourdeur prédomine sur le marché, les affaires sont rares. L'Agricultural et la National réactionnent à 8 9/16-et 23 3/4 respectivement, la Sait and Soda perd un schelling à 19/, l'obligation Crédit. Foncier 2 francs à 327, le Crédit Franco Egyptien 1/16 à 5 3/8 et la Banque d'Qfient 50 centimes à 124 1/2.

Les titres suivants ont été admis aujourd'hui à la cote libre : Eaux d'Alexandrie, du C'uiri; et de Tantah, Wardan Estate, New-Egyptian, Walker ¿i Meimarachi, Mepzqjeh Navigation, Upper Egypt Hotels, Splendid Hotels, Western Egypt Corporation, Heliopolis, Egyptian Mar kets et Cotton Mills.

On assure que des démarches privées sont faites auprès de M. R. Suarès, qui se trouve actuellement à Paris pour qu'il veuille bien employer aon influence auprès des établissements financiers de Paris et de Londres afin de' convertir eh un fait palpable (c'est le cas de le dire) l'aide que les banques avaient promu au marché. A présent quo le plus fort de la crise est passé et qu'une meilleure tendance se dessine, il sera beaucoup plus facile de s'assurer du concours des financiers qu'il y a un mois.

Le concert donné par les élèves du professeur Buzzelli aôbtenu un succès éclatant. MM. Suzaa et Lias se sont particulièrement distin ' gués A.e jeune-A. Stagni s'est révélé un musi cien exquis et plein de grâce.

..W» rceuse de Jocelyn, la Madrigalo de Bimonetti eÇ la Sérénade de Pierné ont été ifélicieusement rendues. Mlle Buzzelli a joué avec beaucoup d'art lé Lamento Gabriel Marie, le Songe de Schumann et la fileuse de Popper.
Le Trio de Mendelssohn a été fort bien interprété par Mme G. B. Alderson, M. Artélli et A. Stagni. Mme O. Cohen et Mlle S» Filus qui tenaient le piano se sont fort distinguées.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS.
div.p: 1. "That -the capital of the Company be increased to £262,500, by the creation of 250,000 additional shares of Is. each."

2. "That 218,264 of such additional shares be offered in the first instance nt a premium of 6d. per share to the members of the Company, in the proportion of one share for every existing share held by them respectively, payable 3d. on application, 6d. on allotment (being the premium) and the balance when required on not less than fourteen day's notice, upon ccnlition that such offer l»e made by notjee specifying the nun. lier of shares to which, the Member is entitled, and limiting the time within which the offer, if not accepted by payment of the amount duo on applicat ion, shall be deemed to be declined, and with a right to shareholders to apply at a premium of 6d. per share, for the excess shares and any shares not taken by Shareholders entitled to apply for the same."

3. "That the Directors be, ami are hereby, empowered and authorised to dispose of the shares not taken in response to such offer, in such manner, at such prices, at such times and generally upon' shch terms and conditions as the Directors.may in their direction think fit "
4. "That Clauses 138 and 158 of the Articles of Association be cancelled -and that the following Clause be substituted, viz:-

130. All shares of the Company for the time' lieing issued, shall rank alike for dividend and in a distribution of assets- on a winding up, notwith-. standing any diffeence in the nominal amounts of any of such shares or in the amounts paid up thereon."
